Sx3.T1.table:
representation count
S​U​B​J​E​C​T​_​I​D𝑆𝑈𝐵𝐽𝐸𝐶𝑇_𝐼𝐷SUBJECT\_ID integer: IDs ranging from 2 to 99,999 30,000
G​E​N​D​E​R𝐺𝐸𝑁𝐷𝐸𝑅GENDER binary: 0 for female and 1 for male 17,284/12,716
A​G​E​_​G​R​O​U​P𝐴𝐺𝐸_𝐺𝑅𝑂𝑈𝑃AGE\_GROUP binary: 0 for ages less than or equal to 65 and 1 for greater 13,947/16,053
M​O​R​T​A​L​I​T​Y𝑀𝑂𝑅𝑇𝐴𝐿𝐼𝑇𝑌MORTALITY binary: 0 for survival and 1 for expired 20,841/9,159
D​R​U​G​S𝐷𝑅𝑈𝐺𝑆DRUGS binary: 0 for not prescribed to patients and 1 for prescribed 2814 dimensions
references: Further joining these two tables on S​U​B​J​E​C​T​_​I​D𝑆𝑈𝐵𝐽𝐸𝐶𝑇_𝐼𝐷SUBJECT\_ID gave a dataset of 30,760 examples, from which we randomly selected 30,000 examples to form the evaluation dataset where D​R​U​G​S𝐷𝑅𝑈𝐺𝑆DRUGS were the predictors and M​O​R​T​A​L​I​T​Y𝑀𝑂𝑅𝑇𝐴𝐿𝐼𝑇𝑌MORTALITY was the response variable. The summary of this dataset was provided in Table 1.

Sx3.T2.caption: Table 2: Example rows and columns of DRUGS.
Sx3.T2.table:
SUBJECT__\_ID D5W Heparin Sodium Nitro-glycerine Docusate Sodium Insulin Atropine Sulphate …
… … … … … … … …
9 1 0 0 0 1 0 …

references: The drug feature contained 2814 different drugs prescribed to the patients. Table 2 shows the first six drugs D5W (that is, 5% dextrose in water), Heparin Sodium, Nitro-glycerine, Docusate Sodium, Insulin and Atropine Sulphate. If a drug was prescribed to a patient (identified by S​U​B​J​E​C​T​_​I​D𝑆𝑈𝐵𝐽𝐸𝐶𝑇_𝐼𝐷SUBJECT\_ID), the corresponding cell in the table would be marked 1, and 0 otherwise. For instance, Patient 9 was given D5W and Insulin while none of the first six drugs were offered to Patient 10.

Sx4.T3.caption: Table 3: IID scenario: 10-fold cross validation results with varying C𝐶C and E𝐸E.
Sx4.T3.table:
C𝐶C E𝐸E FedAvg LoAdaBoost p𝑝p-value
AUC average epochs AUC average epochs
10% 5 0.7891+-0.0002 75 0.7940+-0.0001 68 0.03
10 0.7876+-0.0010 100 0.7900+-0.0007 73 0.03
15 0.7897+-0.0006 75 0.7907+-0.0010 52 0.03
20% 5 0.7905+-0.0003 75 0.7971+-0.0005 69 0.03
50% 5 0.7903+-0.0003 80 0.7932+-0.0005 75 0.03
100% 5 0.7888+-0.0002 75 0.7887+-0.0003 72 0.78
references: To make the superiority of our method more credible, 10-fold cross validation was carried out with different combinations of C𝐶C and E𝐸E, and was repeated for five times under each experimental setting. Wilcox signed rank test was performed on the AUC sets for FedAvg and our method. Average cross validation AUC (with standard deviation), average epochs, and p-values for the statistical test are shown in Table 3.

Sx4.T4.caption: Table 4: Non-IID scenario: 10-fold cross validation results with varying α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta.
Sx4.T4.table:
β𝛽\beta α𝛼\alpha FedAvg with data sharing LoAdaBoost with data sharing p𝑝p-value
AUC average epochs AUC average epochs
1% 10% 0.7842+-0.0016 40 0.7916+-0.0015 36 0.03
20% 0.7954+-0.0012 40 0.8016+-0.0015 35 0.03
30% 0.8167+-0.0011 40 0.8203+-0.0011 34 0.03
2% 10% 0.7913+-0.0010 40 0.7984+-0.0008 35 0.03
3% 10% 0.8033+-0.0010 40 0.8063+-0.0010 34 0.03
references: Same as IID evaluation, 10-fold cross validation was performed for five times. We fixed C𝐶C to 10% and E𝐸E to 5 while varying α𝛼\alpha from 10% to 30% and β𝛽\beta from 1% to 3%. As shown in Table 4, both methods’ AUCs at convergence increased with a larger value of α𝛼\alpha or β𝛽\beta (that is, more data was shared with each client). More importantly, our method always achieved a higher AUC with fewer average epochs.

Sx4.T5.table:
C𝐶C FedAvg with data sharing LoAdaBoost with data sharing p𝑝p-value
AUC average epochs AUC average epochs
10% 0.7842+-0.0016 40 0.7916+-0.0015 36 0.03
20% 0.7869+-0.0008 50 0.7893+-0.0005 46 0.03
50% 0.7831+-0.0005 40 0.7877+-0.0006 35 0.03
100% 0.7609+-0.0004 40 0.7900+-0.0003 35 0.03
references: Moreover, we further investigated the effect of increasing client percentage on predictive performance by fixing α𝛼\alpha=10%, β𝛽\beta=1% and E𝐸E=5 and varying C𝐶C. The 10-fold cross validation results are displayed in Table 5. Our method obtained higher cross validation AUCs than F​e​d​A​v​g𝐹𝑒𝑑𝐴𝑣𝑔FedAvg with data-sharing with C𝐶C=10%, 20%, 50% and 100%, and in all cases each client model under L​o​A​d​a​b​o​o​s​t𝐿𝑜𝐴𝑑𝑎𝑏𝑜𝑜𝑠𝑡LoAdaboost with data-sharing was expected to run less epochs per global round than under F​e​d​A​v​g𝐹𝑒𝑑𝐴𝑣𝑔FedAvg with data-sharing.

Sx4.T6.caption: Table 6: Summary of the eICU dataset.
Sx4.T6.table:
representation count
P​A​T​I​E​N​T​_​U​N​I​T​_​S​T​A​Y​_​I​D𝑃𝐴𝑇𝐼𝐸𝑁𝑇_𝑈𝑁𝐼𝑇_𝑆𝑇𝐴𝑌_𝐼𝐷PATIENT\_UNIT\_STAY\_ID integer: six-digit patient ID 22,500
H​O​S​P​I​T​A​L​_​I​D𝐻𝑂𝑆𝑃𝐼𝑇𝐴𝐿_𝐼𝐷HOSPITAL\_ID integer: hospital IDs ranging from 63 to 458 45
M​O​R​T​A​L​I​T​Y𝑀𝑂𝑅𝑇𝐴𝐿𝐼𝑇𝑌MORTALITY binary: 0 for survival and 1 for expired 21393/1107
D​R​U​G​S𝐷𝑅𝑈𝐺𝑆DRUGS binary: 0 for not prescribed to patients and 1 for prescribed 1399 dimensions
references: To demonstrate the robustness of our method, we included in experiments another critical care dataset from the eICU Collaborative Research Database [18]. The eICU data was in nature non-IID, containing patient data from different hospitals across the US. We sampled 9,000 examples from 30 hospitals, each consisting of 300 examples and serving as a client in the non-IID scenario. The summary of this data is shown in Table 6.

Sx4.T7.caption: Table 7: Evaluation on eICU data: 10-fold cross validation results.
Sx4.T7.table:
data distribution method AUC average epochs p𝑝p-value
IID FedAvg 0.5693+-0.0057 400 0.03
LoAdaBoost 0.6057+-0.0077 262
non-IID FedAvg 0.6512+-0.0043 300 0.03
LoAdaBoost 0.6548+-0.0048 271
FedAvg with data-sharing 0.6253+-0.0088 350 0.03
LoAdaBoost with data-sharing 0.6412+-0.0065 272
references: Federated learning outcomes on eICU were different from those on MIMIC III data. Learning became more difficult as both the baseline and our method took 50 or more global rounds to converge. In addition, as displayed in the figure, AUCs with non-IID data were close to 0.65 but dropped to roughly 0.6 when data-sharing was adopted, while AUCs with IID data were notably lower for both methods. Therefore, learning on non-IID seemed easier than on IID, which resonated with the evaluation results of language modeling on the Shakespeare dataset in McMahan et al.’s work [7]. What was consistent with evaluation on MIMIC III data was that L​o​A​d​a​B​o​o​s​t𝐿𝑜𝐴𝑑𝑎𝐵𝑜𝑜𝑠𝑡LoAdaBoost converged to higher AUCs with fewer average epochs than F​e​d​A​v​g𝐹𝑒𝑑𝐴𝑣𝑔FedAvg, whether the scenario be IID, non-IID or non-IID with data-sharing. This finding was confirmed by the results of 10-fold cross validation with five repetitions (see Table 7).
